translated: The Basket of Conduct
The Third Ground, the Ground of the Suttas

original: Tattha katamaṁ suttādhiṭṭhānaṁ?🔽Lobhādhiṭṭhānaṁ dosādhiṭṭhānaṁ mohādhiṭṭhānaṁ alobhādhiṭṭhānaṁ adosādhiṭṭhānaṁ amohādhiṭṭhānaṁ🔽kāyakammādhiṭṭhānaṁ vācākammādhiṭṭhānaṁ manokammādhiṭṭhānaṁ saddhindriyādhiṭṭhānaṁ
analyzed: tattha kataman sutta adhiṭṭhāna  lobha adhiṭṭhānam dosa adhiṭṭhānam moha adhiṭṭhānam a lobha adhiṭṭhānam a dosa adhiṭṭhānam a moha adhiṭṭhānam  kāya kamma adhiṭṭhānam vācā kamma adhiṭṭhānam manaḥ kamma adhiṭṭhānam saddhindriya adhiṭṭhāna
translated: Herein, what is the ground of the Suttas?🔽The ground of greed, the ground of hate, the ground of delusion, the ground of non-greed, the ground of non-hate, the ground of non-delusion,🔽the ground of bodily action, the ground of verbal action, the ground of mental action, the ground of the faith faculty,

analyzed: vīriya indriya adhiṭṭhānam sati indriya adhiṭṭhānam samādhi indriya adhiṭṭhānam paññindriya adhiṭṭhānam
translated: the ground of the energy faculty, the ground of the mindfulness faculty, the ground of the concentration faculty, the ground of the understanding faculty.
Herein, what is the ground of greed?
“For a man whose thoughts are stirred by thinking,
Whose lust is keen and who contemplates the fair,
Craving grows stronger still:

original: Esa kho gāḷhaṁ karoti bandhanaṁ”.🔽Vitakkamathitassāti kāmarāgo.
analyzed: eṣa khalu gāḍham karoti  vitakka mathitassa ati kāma rāgaḥ
translated: He makes his fetter fast” .
“For a man whose thoughts are stirred by thinking” : greed for sensual desires.🔽“Contemplates the fair” : the basis for greed for sensual desires.

analyzed: bhiyyas taṇhā pavaḍḍhati iti kāma taṇhā
translated: “Craving grows stronger still” : craving for sensual desires.

original: Esa gāḷhaṁ karoti bandhananti rāgaṁ, iti yo yo dhammo mūlanikkhitto, so yevettha dhammo uggāvahitabbo.
analyzed: esa gāḷham karoti rāgaḥ iti yaḥ yaḥ dhammo mūla nikkhitto saḥ yeva ittha dhammo uggāvahitabbo
translated: “He makes his fetter fast” : greed. So whatever idea is stated as the root, that is the idea to be given attention here.

original: Na bhagavā ekaṁ dhammaṁ ārabbha aññaṁ dhammaṁ deseti.
analyzed: na bhagavā ekam dhammam ārabbha aññam dhammam deseti
translated: The Blessed One does not teach one thing in terms of another.

original: Yassa vitakketi kāmavitakko tameva vitakkaṁ kāmavitakkena niddisīyati.🔽Tibbarāgassāti tasseva vitakkassa vatthuṁ niddisati.🔽Subhānupassino bhiyyo taṇhā pavaḍḍhatīti tameva rāgaṁ kāmataṇhāti niddisati.
analyzed: yassa vitakka iti kāma vitakkaḥ tam eva vitakkam kāma vitakkena niddisīyati  tibba rāgassa ati tassa iva vitakkassa vatthum niddisati  subha anupassinaḥ bhiyyas taṇhā pavaḍḍhati iti tam eva rāgam kāma taṇhā iti niddisati
translated: When one thinks a thought of sense desire, that thought is demonstrated by the thought of sense desire.🔽“With strong lust” demonstrates the object of that thought.🔽“With the contemplation of beauty, craving increases” demonstrates that lust itself as sense desire.

original: Esa gāḷhaṁ karoti bandhananti tameva taṇhāsaṁyojanaṁ niddisati.
analyzed: esa gāḷham karoti tam eva taṇhā sayojanam niddisati
translated: “Thus he makes it strong, makes it grow” demonstrates that craving itself as the fetter of sense desire.
This is how the verse should be inferred.
This is how in the case of the Sayings.

original: Tattha bhagavā ekaṁ dhammaṁ tividhaṁ niddisati, nissandato hetuto phalato.
analyzed: tattha bhagavā ekam dhammam tividham niddisati nissandataḥ hetutaḥ phalataḥ
translated: Herein, the Blessed One demonstrates one thing in three ways, namely, by outcome, by cause, and by fruit.
“He is dear when he gives, many frequent him,
He gains fame and his reputation grows;
He goes to meet an assembly without fear,
A man is confident and not miserly” .

original: Dadanti yaṁ yaṁ dānaṁ, idaṁ dānamayikaṁ puññakriyaṁ.🔽Tattha hetu.
analyzed: dadanti yam yam dāne idam dānamayikam puñña kriya  tattha hetu
translated: Whatever gift he gives is the meritorious action consisting in giving.🔽Herein, the cause is
“And that” .

original: Bhajanti naṁ bahū, kittinti yo ca kalyāṇo kittisaddo loke abbhuggacchati, yaṁ bahukassa janassa piyo bhavati manāpo ca.
analyzed: bhajanti nam bahū yaḥ ca kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ loke abbhuggacchati yam bahukassa janassa piyaḥ bhavati manāpaḥ ca
translated: He is frequented by many, he has a good reputation: the good reputation of him who has gone forth spreads in the world, he is dear to and beloved of many people.

original: Yañca avippaṭisārī kālaṁ karoti ayaṁ nissando.
analyzed: yat ca a vippaṭisārī kālam karoti ayam nissandaḥ
translated: He dies unconfused: this is the outcome.

original: Yaṁ kāyassa bhedā devesu upapajjatīti idaṁ phalaṁ.
analyzed: yam kāyassa bhedā devesu upapajjati iti idam phala
translated: And after death he arises in the company of the Divinities: this is the fruit.
This is the basis of greed.
Herein, what is the basis of hate?
“He who kills a breathing thing,

analyzed: musāvādañca bhāsati  loke a dinnam ādiyati
translated: And speaks the word of falsehood,🔽And takes what is not given him,

analyzed: paradārañca gacchati  surā meraya pānam ca
translated: And goes to others’ wives,🔽And drinks the spirits that inebriate,
The man who indulges in these things,
Not having abandoned the five bonds,
Is called ‘unvirtuous’;
And when his body breaks up, the witless one
Arises in the Hell of Compression”.

analyzed: yaḥ pāṇam atipāteti iti duṭṭhaḥ pāṇam atipāteti
translated: He who kills a breathing thing: the hater kills a breathing thing.

analyzed: musā vādañca bhāsati iti dosa upaghātāya musā vādañca bhāsati
translated: And speaks the word of falsehood: he speaks the word of falsehood for the purpose of deceiving and deluding.

original: Surāmerayapānañca, yo naro anuyuñjatīti doso nidānaṁ.
analyzed: surā meraya pānam ca yaḥ naraḥ anuyuñjati iti dosaḥ
translated: And drinks the spirits that inebriate: hate is the source.

original: Yo ca surāmerayapānaṁ anuyuñjati yathāparadāravihārī amittā janayanti.
analyzed: yaḥ ca surā meraya pānam anuyuñjati yathā apara dāra vihārī amittāḥ janayanti
translated: and he who indulges in drinking liquor and spirits generates enemies as does he who misconducts himself with another’s wife.

original: Pañca verāni appahāyāti pañcannaṁ bhikkhāpadānaṁ samatikkamanaṁ sabbesaṁ dosajānaṁ
analyzed: pañca verāni appahāya ati pañcannam bhikkhāpadānam samatikkamanam sabbesam dosa jāna
translated: “Not having abandoned the five hindrances”: the transgression of the five precepts, all the kinds of hate,

original: sā paṇṇatti, teneva dosajanitena kammena dussīlo iti vuccati sopi dhammo hetunā niddisitabbo,
analyzed: sā paṇṇatti tena iva dosa janitena kammena dussīlaḥ iti vuccati saḥ api dhammaḥ hetunā niddisitabbo
translated: is the description of that. By that action born of hate he is called “unvirtuous”. That state should be demonstrated by its cause,
by its outcome and by its fruit.
There are three characteristics of a fool:

original: dubbhāsitabhāsī ca hoti, duccintitacintī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca.
analyzed: dubbhāsita bhāsī ca hoti duccintita cintī ca dukkaṭa kamma kārī ca
translated: he speaks what is badly spoken, he thinks what is badly thought, he does what is badly done.

original: Tattha yaṁ kāyena ca vācāya ca parakkamati, idamassa dukkaṭakammakārī.
analyzed: tattha yam kāyena ca vācāya ca parakkamati idam assa dukkaṭa kamma kārī
translated: Herein, what he does by body and by speech is his doing what is badly done.

original: Tāyaṁ yathā ca musāvādaṁ bhāsati yathā pubbaniddiṭṭhaṁ, idamassa dubbhāsitā.
analyzed: yathā ca musāvādam bhāsati yathā pubba niddiṭṭhaḥ idam assa dubbhāsi tā
translated: And as he speaks a lie as already described, this is his speaking what is badly spoken.

original: Yañca saṅkappeti manoduccaritaṁ byāpādaṁ, idamassa duccintitacintitā.
analyzed: yat ca saṅkappeti manaḥ duccaritam byāpādaḥ idam assa duccintita cinti tā
translated: And what he intends, the mental misconduct of ill will, this is his thinking what is badly thought.

original: Yaṁ so imehi tīhi bālalakkhaṇehi samannāgato tīṇi tajjāni dukkhāni domanassāni anubhavati, so ca hoti sabhaggato vā parisaggato vā tajjaṁ kathaṁ kathanti.
analyzed: yam saḥ imehi tīhi bāla lakkhaṇehi samannāgataḥ tīṇi tajjāni dukkhāni domanassāni anubhavati saḥ ca hoti sabhaggataḥ vā parisaggataḥ vā tajjam katham katham ti
translated: He who is endowed with these three characteristics of a fool experiences three kinds of suffering and sorrow that are born from them. And he is a topic of conversation in the village or in the town.

original: Yadā bhavati so ca pāṇātipātādidasaakusalakammapatho, so tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedetīti.
analyzed: yadā bhavati saḥ ca pāṇātipāta ādi dasa akusala kamma patho so tatonidānam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti iti
translated: When he is, then that is the unprofitable course of action consisting in killing living beings, and he experiences suffering and sorrow born from that.

original: Puna caparaṁ yadā passati coraṁ rājāparādhikaṁ raññā gahitaṁ jīvitā voropetaṁ, tassevaṁ
analyzed: puna ca param yadā passati coram rāja aparādhikam raññā gahitam jīvitā tassa iva
translated: Again, when he sees a thief who has offended against the king, caught by the king, sentenced to death,

original: bhavati sace mamampi rājā jāneyya mamampi rājā gāhāpetvā jīvitā voropeyyāti, so tatonidānaṁ🔽dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: bhavati sace mamampi rājā jāneyya mamampi rājā gāhāpetvā jīvitā voropeyya ati saḥ tatonidāna  dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: he thinks: “If the king were to know about me, he would have me caught and sentenced to death.” He experiences suffering and sorrow born from that.

original: Puna caparaṁ bālo yadā bhavati āsanā samārūḷho yāva yā me gati bhavissati ito pecca paraṁ maraṇāti so tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti iti bālalakkhaṇaṁ hetu.
analyzed: puna ca param bālaḥ yadā bhavati āsanā samārūḍhaḥ yāva yā me gati bhavissati itas pecca param so tatonidānam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti iti bāla lakkhaṇam hetu
translated: Again, when a fool is seated in his seat, he thinks: “Where will my destiny be after I die from here?” He experiences suffering and sorrow born from that. Thus the characteristics of a fool are the cause.
The three kinds of suffering and sorrow that are born from them are the result.

original: Kāyassa bhedā nirayesu upapajjati, idaṁ phalaṁ.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā nirayesu upapajjati idam phala
translated: At the break-up of the body after death he is reborn in hell. This is the fruit.
This is the case of the footing in hate.
Herein, what is the case of the footing in delusion?
“For a hundred or a thousand aeons,
He will wander in rebirths,
Or even more than that,
From womb to womb.
Without taking the Buddha’s word,
Taking determinations as self,
They will not make an end of suffering:
This is not the way to do it”.

original: Yo yaṁ anamataggasaṁsāraṁ samāpanno jāyate ca mīyate ca, ayaṁ avijjāhetukā.
analyzed: yaḥ yam anamatagga sasāram samāpannaḥ jāyate ca mīyate ca ayam avijjā hetukā
translated: Whoever has come to the beginningless round of rebirths and is reborn and dies, this is due to ignorance.

original: Yānipi ca saṅkhārānaṁ payojanāni, tānipi avijjāpaccayāni, yaṁ adassanaṁ buddhavacanassa, ayaṁ avijjāsutteyeva niddiṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: yāni api ca saṅkhārānam payojanāni tāni api avijjā paccayāni yam a dassanam buddha vacanassa ayam
translated: And the purposes of determinations are also due to ignorance. The non-seeing of the Buddha’s word is demonstrated in the Thread on Ignorance.

original: Yo ca saṅkhāre attato harati pañcakkhandhe pañca diṭṭhiyo upagacchati.
analyzed: yaḥ ca saṅkhāre attataḥ harati pañca kkhandhe pañca diṭṭhiyaḥ upagacchati
translated: And whoever takes determinations as self, he takes the five categories as the five views.

original: “Etaṁ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti idaṁ suttaṁ avijjāya nikkhittaṁ, avijjāya nikkhipitaṁ.
analyzed: etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati idam suttam avijjāya nikkhitta avijjāya nikkhipita
translated: “This is mine, this I am, this is my self” : this Thread is placed in ignorance, it is placed by ignorance.

original: Evaṁ satthā sutte nayena dhammena niddisati.🔽Asādhāraṇena taṁyeva tattha niddisitabbaṁ.
analyzed: evam satthā sutte nayena dhammena niddisati  asādhāraṇena tayā iva tattha
translated: So the Exalted One demonstrates by the Thread, by the method, by the Dhamma.
By the uncommon he should demonstrate just that there and not another.

original: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā “idaṁ dukkhan”ti nappajānanti cattāri saccāni vitthārena, yaṁ tattha appajānanā, idaṁ dukkhaṁ, ayaṁ hetu.
analyzed: ye hi keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā idam dukkhan ti na pajānanti cattāri saccāni vitthārena yam tattha appajānanā idam dukkha ayam hetu
translated: For whatever ascetics and priests do not understand the four Truths in detail as “This is suffering” and so on, the not understanding there is suffering, this is the cause.

original: Appajānanto vividhe saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharoti, ayaṁ nissando.
analyzed: appajānantaḥ vividhe saṅkhāre abhisaṅkharoti ayam nissandaḥ
translated: Not understanding, he instigates the various determinations, this is the outcome.

original: Yañca diṭṭhigatāni parāmasati “idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan”ti ayaṁ nissando.
analyzed: yat ca diṭṭhi gatāni parāmasati idam eva saccam mogham aññanti ayam nissandaḥ
translated: And whatever he misconstrues as views, “This alone is the truth, other ideas are silly,” this is the outcome.
And whatever he generates as renewed existence, this is the fruit.

original: Ayampi dhammo saniddiṭṭho hetuto ca phalato ca nissandato ca.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sa niddiṭṭhaḥ hetuto ca phalato ca nissandato ca
translated: This Dhamma too is demonstrated by cause, fruit, and outcome.

original: Ettha pana keci dhammā sādhāraṇā bhavanti.
analyzed: ettha pana keci dhammā sādhāraṇāḥ bhavanti
translated: But here some ideas are shared in common.

analyzed: hetu khalu āditoyā iva sutte nikkhipissanti
translated: For the cause will be put forward in the Thread right at the beginning.

original: Yathā kiṁ bhave cattārimāni, bhikkhave, agatigamanāni.
analyzed: yathā kim bhave cattāri imāni bhikkhave agati gamanāni
translated: As to how? “Bhikkhus, there are these four ways of undertaking things that are on the side of decline.

original: Tattha yañca chandāgatiṁ gacchati yañca bhayāgatiṁ gacchati, ayaṁ lobho akusalamūlaṁ.
analyzed: tattha yat ca chandāgatim gacchati yat ca bhayāgatim gacchati ayam lobhaḥ akusala mūla
translated: Herein, the greed that goes by the will’s impulse and the fear that goes by the will’s impulse are the unprofitable root hate.
The hate that goes by hate is just hate.
The delusion that goes by delusion is just delusion.

original: Evaṁ imāni tīṇi akusalamūlāni āditoyeva upaparikkhitabbāni.
analyzed: evam imāni tīṇi akusala mūlāni āditoyā iva upaparikkhitabbāni
translated: So these three unprofitable roots should be investigated right at the start.

original: Yattha ekaṁ niddisitabbaṁ, tattha ekaṁ niddisīyati.
translated: Where one can be demonstrated, there one is demonstrated.

original: Tathā dve yathā tīṇi, na hi ādīhi anikkhitte hetu vā nissando vā phalaṁ vā niddisitabbaṁ.
analyzed: tathā dve yathā tīṇi na hi ādīhi a nikkhitte hetu vā nissandaḥ vā phalam vā
translated: So too with two, and so with three, for no cause, outcome, or fruit can be demonstrated without a start.
Herein, this is the verse:
By will, by hate, by fear, by dullness,
He who transgresses the True Idea,
His fame declines,
Like the moon in waning fortnight.

original: Kattha chandā ca ayaṁ lobho yathā niddiṭṭhaṁ pubbe.
analyzed: kattha chandā ca ayam lobho yathā niddiṭṭham pubbe
translated: Herein, the will is greed as already described.
This is the footing for delusion.
Herein, what is the footing for non-greed?
“He who abides contemplating foulness,
Well-restrained in the faculties,🔽Knowing the right amount in nutriment,
Faithful, with energy aroused,
Mara cannot get at him,
like the wind a mountain cloud.

original: Tattha yā asubhāya upaparikkhā, ayaṁ kāmesu ādīnavadassanena pariccāgo.🔽Indriyesu susaṁvuto tasseva alobhassa pāripūriyaṁ mama āyatanasocitaṁ anupādāya.
analyzed: tattha yā asubhāya upaparikkhā ayam kāmesu ādīnava dassanena pariccāgaḥ  indriyesu tassa iva alobhassa pāripūriyam mama an upādāya
translated: Herein, the investigation of the unattractive is the giving up by seeing the danger in sensual desires.🔽The restraint of the faculties is the fulfilment of that same non-greed. The avoidance of storing is the giving up by seeing the escape from sensual desires.
The moderation in food is the abandoning of craving for tastes.

original: Iti ayaṁ alobho asubhānupassitāya vatthuto dhārayati, so alobho hetu.
analyzed: iti ayam alobhaḥ asubha anupassitāya vatthutaḥ dhārayati saḥ alobhaḥ hetu
translated: So this non-greed is borne in being by the contemplation of the unattractive as the object. That non-greed is the cause.

original: Indriyesu guttadvāratāya gocarato dhārayati, bhojanemattaññutāya parato dhārayati, ayaṁ nissando.
analyzed: indriyesu guttadvāra tāya gocarataḥ dhārayati bhojanemattaññutāya paratas dhārayati ayam nissandaḥ
translated: It is borne in being by the guardedness of the sense faculties as the province. It is borne in being by moderation in food as the opposite. This is the outcome.

original: Taṁ ve nappasahati māro, vāto selaṁ va pabbatanti, idaṁ phalaṁ.
analyzed: tam ve nappasahati māraḥ vātaḥ selam va idam phala
translated: Māra cannot overthrow him, like the wind a mountain cloud. This is the fruit.

original: Iti yoyeva dhammo ādimhi nikkhitto, soyeva majjhe ceva avasāne ca.
analyzed: iti yaḥ yeva dhammaḥ ādimhi nikkhitto saḥ yeva majjhe ca iva avasāne ca
translated: So the idea stated at the beginning is repeated both in the middle and at the end.

original: Nāhaṁ, bhikkhave, aññaṁ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi asamuppannassa kāmacchandassa anuppādāya uppannassa vā pahānāya, yathayidaṁ asubhanimittaṁ.
analyzed: na aha bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi a samuppannassa kāmacchandassa anuppādāya uppannassa vā pahānāya yathayidam asubha nimitta
translated: I see no other single thing, bhikkhus, that so effectively prevents the arising of unarisen sensual desire and leads to the abandonment of arisen sensual desire as the contemplation of the unattractive.

original: Tattha asubhanimittaṁ manasikarontassa anuppanno ceva kāmacchando na uppajjati, uppanno ca kāmacchando pahīyati.
analyzed: tattha asubha nimittam manasikarontassa anuppannaḥ ca iva kāmacchandaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ ca kāmacchandaḥ pahīyati
translated: Herein, when he gives attention to a foul object, then unarisen sensual desire does not arise and arisen sensual desire is abandoned.
This is the basis for non-greed.

original: Yaṁ puna anuppanno kāmarāgo pariyādiyati rūparāgaṁ arūparāgaṁ, iti phalaṁ.
analyzed: yam puna an uppannaḥ kāma rāgaḥ rūpa rāgam a rūpa rāgaḥ iti
translated: And the non-arising of arisen greed for visible forms, etc., is the outcome.

original: Iti ayampi ca dhammo niddiṭṭho hetuto ca nissandato ca phalato ca.
analyzed: iti ayam pi ca dhammaḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ hetuto ca nissandato ca phalato ca
translated: So this idea too has been taught by the Blessed One with cause and with outcome.
This is the demonstration of non-greed.
Herein, what is the demonstration of non-hate?

analyzed: ekam pi ce pāṇam a duṭṭha cittaḥ
translated: “If he is kindly to one being only,

original: Mettāyati kusalo tena hoti;🔽Sabbe ca pāṇe manasānukampaṁ,
analyzed: mettāyati kusalaḥ tena hoti  sabbe ca pāṇe manasā anukampa
translated: He is reckoned as skilled in benevolence;🔽But the noble person’s benevolence
Is extended to all living beings” .

original: Ekampi ce pāṇamaduṭṭhacitto mettāyatīti ayaṁ adoso.
analyzed: ekam pi ce pāṇam aduṭṭha cittaḥ mettāyati iti ayam adosaḥ
translated: “If he is kindly to one being only” : this is non-hate.

original: Nigghātena assādo, kusalo tena hotīti tena kusalena dhammena saṁyutto dhammapaññattiṁ gacchati.
analyzed: nigghātena assādo kusalo tena hoti iti tena kusalena dhammena sayuttaḥ dhamma paññattim gacchati
translated: “He is reckoned as skilled in benevolence” : the satisfaction is by way of the negation. He is reckoned as having the idea of skill in virtue.

original: Kusaloti yathā paññāya pañño paṇḍiccena paṇḍito.
analyzed: kusalaḥ ti yathā paññāya paññaḥ paṇḍiccena paṇḍitaḥ
translated: “Skilled” : as one who is wise by way of understanding, clever by way of cleverness.

original: Pahūtamariyo pakaroti puññanti tassāyeva vipāko ayaṁ lokiyassa, na hi lokuttarassa.
analyzed: pahūta mariyaḥ pakaroti vipākaḥ ayam lokiyassa na hi lokuttarassa
translated: “The Noble One makes much merit” : this is the outcome in the world, not in the supramundane.
